Topic.Title: BEZOS SCAM LAUGH HYPE MACHINE PEAK TODAY?KINDLE SCAM HYPE BARKING...

Message.Msg: Is it a Kindle? Join CNET at 10 a.m. PT for Amazon press event (live blog) The online-retail giant has invited press to a gathering, though it hasn't said what's on tap. Signs point toward Kindle updates, including a zippier, higher-resolution Kindle Fire. CNET will be there to bring you the news live. Nokia and Motorola have had their say, and Apple and Nintendo are still a week away. But the parade of gadget unveilings known in techdom as September continues today with Amazon set to take the wraps off a new batch of Kindle devices in Santa Monica, Calif. The company has said only that it is hosting a press conference, without divulging details of what it will discuss. But several leaks -- and the fact that it's been nearly a year since the last hardware refresh -- point to a range of new Kindle devices. CNET reported last week that Amazon will debut two 7-inch Kindle Fires at the event, including a high-end model with a zippy processor, a camera, physical volume controls, an HDMI port, and larger storage than a second, more bare-bones version. It seems likely that Amazon will also increase the resolution on the Kindle Fire's display. It may even subsidize the cost of the device with an ad-supported version, as it has with a lower-cost Kindle e-reader. And it seems all but certain that Amazon will update its Kindle e-ink readers as well, with a "Paperwhite" backlit model rumored. The press conference begins at 10:30 a.m. PT today. We'll be kicking off our coverage a bit earlier (around 10 a.m. PT). Join us from the Barker Hangar -- yep, the company has rented a hangar -- as we cover the event live.

Message.Msg: No1 GLOBAL CLOUD/LICENSE SOFTWARE PROVIDER FOR LEASING AND FINANCING APPLICATIONS............... TARGET $10+ ............ANALYST AVERAGE TARGET: $16 .............MAX: $21 ===== 9/4/2012 NTWK REPORTED RECORD 4Q AND FULL YEAR RESULTS - Fourth Quarter 2012 Revenue Surges to an all-time quarterly record of $14.3 Million on Increased License Revenues and associated maintenance and service agreements going forward - Fourth Quarter 2012 Earnings Advance Significantly to $0.25 per Diluted Share - Full Year 2012 revenues a record $38M - Full Year 2012 Earnings of $0.39/share - Company Expects Record Fiscal 2013 Annual Revenue Growing over 30% to $46 million to $49 million, With Earnings per Diluted Share Advancing to $0.80 to $1.00 - Per the CC, Company expects to DOUBLE REVENUES/NET INCOME by 2015 ==== NTWK HIGHLIGHTS: - Fast growing profitable US-based global cloud and license-based software company with 8 offices worldwide (US, China, Australia, UK, Pakistan, Singapore, Thailand, Saudi Arabia) – - Trading at 5 PE and 1 times sales – This is about 25% of sector average - Revenues are increasing at double digit rates, - Guidance calls for 30% revenue growth in 2013 - 3 consecutive quarters of profitability, - Guidance calls for $1/share net income in 2013!!! - Global alliances with Mercedes Benz and SANY Corp of China. - No. 1 in China and the APAC region in its niche market of leasing and financing software - It’s Vroozi Division is a fast growing Cloud Computing Play with strong relations with SAP, ORCL, MSFT. - Vroozi’s SAP-approved smartOCI procurement search catalog software built on SaaS is being adopted rapidly. Revenues exploded in 4Q 2012 and are expected to multiply in 2013 and a big reason for the 30%+ 2013 projected revenue increase - Vroozi has been created as independent entity to potentially IPO it or sell it to a cloud-acquiring giant like SAP and others - Strong balance sheet with $1/share Cash - With every license they sell a lucrative 5-year service and maintenance agreement building strong recurrent revenues - Huge and consistent insider buying. Insiders bought over 5% of the outstanding shares since 2010 - Strong institutional investor support grew to almost 20% from 11% last year - NTWK has over 50 Fortune 100 loyal customers. Never lost a customer. None of the customers is over 5% of the total revenues - partial customer list: CitiGroup, Mercedes Benz, Santander, BMW, Volvo, Ford, GE Capital, Cisco Capital, Paribas, GMAC, Toyota, Nissan, Hyundai, BYD, SANY Corp. China, etc. TAKE A LOOK AT NTWK's CHART........SIMILAR TECHNICAL & FUNDAMENTAL CONDITIONS MADE THE STOCK TRIPLE IN 2007 and 2010

Message.Title: THIS DAY SCAMZON HYPE PEAK CLIFF:Amazon's Risky Bet on Profit-Free Hardware
Message.Msg: Amazon's Risky Bet on Profit-Free Hardware Nobody else seems to be saying it, so I will: Amazon and Google are playing a dangerous game. The name of that game: Profit-free hardware. We've come to know the results as the Kindle Fire and the Nexus 7. Today at Amazon's [AMZN 251.38 5.16 (+2.1%) ] event in L.A., we expect to see the next phase of its vision, even as Google ramps up shipments of its tablet. Both have 7-inch screens, running different versions of the Android operating system. Both started out costing about $200 to make. And both have sold for about $200. (Read More: Amazon Expected to Unveil New Kindle as Tablet Wars Heat Up ) Amazon and Google [GOOG 699.40 18.68 (+2.74%) ] can do this — for a while. They can do it because they have high-growth, multi-billion-dollar revenue businesses. Amazon booked $12.8 billion in net revenue last quarter, and Google $12.2 billion. And they can also do it because the math works, at least for now. Amazon and Google both know that if people buy and use their cheap tablets, it will drive more Google searches and Amazon purchases. But I think that it's important to note that there are scenarios where this could end badly for either company. For a case in point, look at what happened to HP's [HPQ 17.59 0.32 (+1.85%) ] TouchPad tablet. In case you've forgotten (or blocked it from memory if you were an HP investor), the TouchPad launched about 14 months ago at $499, the same price as the iPad. It didn't sell. Less than six weeks later, HP killed it off ... sort of. The company actually discounted it dramatically to clear inventory, finding that while it was a dog at $499, it was a hot item at $99 or $199. Even so, HP ended up taking a $3.3 billion write-down to shutter the business and the webOS platform. That's the trouble with hardware. If it flops and flops badly, it can vaporize profits. There are big costs that go along with guaranteeing manufacturing capacity, securing components, predicting demand, building up inventory and distributing product. At the moment there's no clear sign that either Amazon or Google's efforts will fail as spectacularly as HP's did. But with Apple [AAPL 676.27 6.04 (+0.9%) ] poised to compete in the sub-$300 tablet space where these guys are barely breaking even anyway, the risks keep getting more serious. We'll see if Amazon's announcement today does anything to make the high-end Kindle more of a sure thing.

Message.Title: The Emperor Has No Clothes
Message.Msg: I truly believe we are now living in a world where the emperor has no clothes. Central Banks can print infinite money for awhile, as if that is the true solution to a debt crisis. More debt. But what else can they do? In the meantime, as this asset bubble lifts paper assets and real yield disappears, it is easy to pump a favorite bubble stock with borrowed money. Since AMZN carries no valuation metrics, there is no ceiling in the short term for a company that earns little to no money. As long as AMZN isn't losing money. But wait, that is about to happen sooner rather than later. Sales taxes in California are very real, and very relevant. Witness the pre-buying going on now in California as buyers race to beat the deadline. If taxes have such little effect, why pay attention to the deadline? Because taxes do matter to consumers. They matter a lot. Meanwhile, AMZN's press conference was a total joke. Not one distinguishing feature on their lineup of new devices, save for a better backlight on their Kindle readers. I would hope so. Who is going to buy an e-reader if they can't read the books? Meanwhile, their tablet competitors were a joke vs the new lineup of Google NEXUS and Apple IPAD devices. No distinguishing features at all to draw in new customers. And if AMZN truly is giving the devices away to get the content business, which has yet to be profitable for distributors (even the mighty AAPL), why not backwards integrate the software upgrade for existing device users? After all, AMZN is the master of the cloud, and flashing a few million devices with a software upgrade through the cloud should be easy, right? AMZN is a joke of a company. Bezos is the best con man in the world. At least PT Barnum had to pretend to do something magical. Bezos just stands up there in a blazer and a bald head, shows some mediocre wannabe devices, and watches as the central banks buy up his stock through the Fidelity-Goldman cartel. What a joke our government has become. The Emperor truly has no clothes.

Message.Title: WOW! PE over 306 and forward PE over 105 - AMZN is like unstoppable locomotive
Message.Msg: Risk-reward tradeoff is changing fast - tiny upside potential (analysts est for 12-month high of 266) but huge downside risk. Their new machines are priced so low (barely recover costs), it would be interesting to see how margin will change as they start selling new machines. It is kind of hardware lineup so margin could deteriorate pretty quickly. AMZN, LNKD, and GOOG area fast becoming over-priced. I worry about these kinds of bubbles bringing down the whole market. It's time to be cautious in long positions and protect via put options. Short selling can be dangerous because of the risk of short squeeze, although at some point these stocks will peak but at what price?

Message.Title: Fire HD vs Nexus 7
Message.Msg: -Nexus...CPU 1.3GHz quad core. Fire...1.2GHz dual core. -Nexus OS...Android 4.1. Fire...Android (forked with unknown version). -Nexus display protection...Corning glass. Fire...scratch resistant glass. -Nexus weight...340g. Fire weight...390g. -Nexus display...LED backlit. Fire...LCD backlit (faster battery drain). Even a noob knows that the Nexus 7 is a better buy! Yes, boys and girls, the new $199 7" Fire HD is vastly inferior to the $199 Nexus 7.

Imagine how many new kindle fires they will be left with when they don't sell because every single kid asks for the galaxy s 3 and not the kindle, parents figure a way to stay connected and keep track of them. Wow Amazon,another reason to short your stock,you are only 120 days too late for serious success, you needed to be out with this plan 120 days at least before the Samsung Galaxy s 3 was out! Because of all the apple limitations and rules on the iphone to enrich apple way more then they deserve selling products priced 1000.00 more then a windows with lower specs to idiots and sorry GPU's but in this economy, no jobs, a realistic 15 or 20% unemployment everywhere, people are only going to spend 600 bucks plus tax a couple times for maybe themselves and a girlfriend or boyfriend, mom or a dad and it will be on the Galaxy s 3, as smaller, can do anything, easier to take anywhere,can buy unlocked and then get a cheap pre paid service plan on it and be on it on free wifi anywhere you go with wifi, work or school, a friends, use off your friends wifi tether and all that. Yes I would have gotten the max kindle fire for 600 over the control what I want to do iphone, I use piratebay,like to download movies and music, apple has a problem with this, android and galaxy s 3 does not, and 9 out of ten people who already have some type of tablet or a laptop will ask for the Samsung Galaxy s 3 over the kindle for Christmas,as the 20 million sold in last 100 days proves to you, they see their friends and immediately go buy one or save for one. Also those like me that were waiting for the best Android yet and for them to get Android software perfect, now that they have are buying their 1st smart phone and its a 600.00 galaxy s 3. Why do I stress this and why does it matter? Amazon has right idea but bad timing, they will lose alot over this deal and have a huge writedown either 2nd quarter of 3rd earnings quarter of 2013, factor in what might and should be the worst economy the world has ever seen with all the many things expiring and a congress that does nothing. Amazon is going to get whacked for 50 bucks down day soon or 75 points in 3 days once analysts figure it out and write the story. It comes down to everyone would only get the new kindle fire if they didn't get the old one and already have a galaxy s 3 lol! I see massive writedowns after a huge stock crash between oct 2012 and april 2013 like max kaiser said on Alex Jones show, hsbc and jp morgan in big big trouble, enough possibly to wipe out the federal reserve they said is certainly possible, I don't know if I go that far but I feel the deep problems behind the service.

Message.Title: Why AMZN's strategy won't work...
Message.Msg: Bezo's is partially right to say they don't wan't to make money on the device, but on the usage of the device. It's right as the content will be able to generate most of the value, whereas the devices will eventually become commoditized to some degree. The issue is, content owners won't want to provide exclusivity to AMZN unless they have leadership share. Even if AMZN can increase their share to 30%, Why would an author, musician, programmer, etc give exclusivity to AMZN and lose out on 70% of the market? Any major content owner won't do this. What they will do is either a) grand exclusivity to the biggest player (assuming reasonable terms can be agreed) or b) grant non-exclusive rights. In the case of non-exclusive rights, hardware vendors will be more price competitive driving down content costs. Since AAPL makes attractive margins on iPad, they won't have an issue with this. AMZN, however will end up selling hardware at cost, and content at a low margin. AMZN is an amazing company with huge and growing infuence, but I don't foresee the Kindle platform becoming a major value driver for the company, but rather a way to maintain the losses from consumers moving to digital content by at least keeping their portion of the revenue.
